newsitem.title: USA: NHL ICE HOCKEY-FLYERS HAVE BACKS TO THE WALL AGAINST FLYING RED WINGS.
newsitem.headline: NHL ICE HOCKEY-FLYERS HAVE BACKS TO THE WALL AGAINST FLYING RED WINGS.

text.p: The last team to trail the Detroit Red Wings by three games to none in the Stanley Cup playoffs won four straight to win the title.
Philadelphia Flyers coach Terry Murray, whose team will try to stave off elimination on Saturday, is thinking in much more modest terms.
"We are not looking at four games," admitted a sombre Murray. "We want to win one period first, then build on it and try and win just one game."

In 1942 the Detroit Red Wings shocked the Toronto Maple Leafs, winning the first two games of the Stanley Cup final at Maple Leaf Gardens and then taking a commanding three games to none lead in Game 3 in Detroit. Toronto, however, swept the next four.
Murray says the Flyers, who have lost the first three games in this series, must improve in every area to become competitive against Detroit.

"It isn't just (goalie) Ron Hextall, we need to improve in every facet of our play," said Murray. "Eric Lindros's confidence level is down, and we are giving them too many odd man rushes. We have to come out and play with great intensity, and build on that.
"We held a meeting, just the players and the three coaches, and we talked it through. It was good therapy. The only yelling was done by myself."
Action, not words, will determine whether the Flyers can get back into the Stanley Cup on Saturday despite being winless in Joe Louis Arena since 1988.
Said Hextall: "Thursday night's loss (6-1) wasn't the most fun I have had in my life. What hurts is we worked all year to get to the Finals and now we are playing our worst hockey of the season."
The confident Red Wings need only one win to end a 42-year Stanley Cup drought with their eighth title triumph.

Joey Kocur, the hard nosed right wing whose goal was so important in Game 1, said, "This is a special time in Detroit hockey. We have to stay focused and get the job done, the quicker the better. They will play desperate.
"Guys will say they are not thinking about winning it all tomorrow, but they are. I may have some trouble sleeping tonight."

Red Wing captain and centre Steve Yzerman, said: "I think we are trying to just stay relaxed. I think it has helped us to not get too carried away when things go wrong, and not to get too excited when they go right."
Detroit coach Scotty Bowman, bidding for his seventh Stanley Cup victory, acknowledged some concerns. "Keeping the focus on hockey and not tickets and all the hype is tough."

If the Wings win Bowman will become the first coach to win Stanley Cup titles with three teams -- Montreal, Pittsburgh and Detroit. Toe Blake of Montreal with eight Cup wins in 13 seasons is the all-time leader.
One old time Red Wing, Ted Lindsay, the captain of the 1955 Stanley Cup champions, and a very active member of the Red Wing Alumni, has been visiting the locker room on occasion and working out.
Lindsay, called Old Scar Face, said: "If they win Saturday I will be just like any other hysterical fan. I won't go to the dressing room, this is their time.
"This championship will be great for the Red Wings, and the City of Detroit. It's been a long time coming."
